title: Harvey Keitel, 80, looks smitten with wife Daphna Kastner, 58, as they hold hands in New York City
text:
He's set to appear alongside fellow acting legends Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Joe Pesci in Martin Scorsese's The Irishman.

And Harvey Keitel enjoyed a relaxing stroll alongside his wife Daphna Kastner, 58, while out in New York City on Tuesday.

The actor, 80, looked more loved up than ever with his actress wife of 18 years, as he interlocked his hands with hers during their walk.

Loved-up: Harvey Keitel, 80, looked smitten with his chic wife Daphna Kastner, 58, as they held hands while enjoying a relaxing stroll in New York City on Tuesday

Harvey looked sharp as he had buttoned up a dark blue blazer over a simple black shirt and matching trousers.

Meanwhile, Daphna opted to keep things casually chic as she wore a long-sleeved grey top over a purple T-Shirt.

The Canadian actress accentuated her slender figure by wearing a pair of black leggings, and she completed the look with a pair of black trainers and white socks.

Her brunette locks were styled into loose curls, while she wore a light palette of make-up to highlight her pretty features.

Casual: Harvey looked sharp as he had buttoned up a dark blue blazer over a simple black shirt and matching trousers

Comfy: The Canadian actress accentuated her slender figure by wearing a pair of black leggings, and she completed the look with a pair of black trainers and white socks

At The Irishman's London premiere on Sunday, Harvey spoke with MailOnline about the difference between working with De Niro, Pacino, and director Scorsese this time around, compared to their past projects.

'I hope I’m right when I say I think we’ve mellowed somewhat,' he said. 'I don’t think anybody has slowed down at all, I think things have gotten deeper, richer, more vital. We won’t slow down, we’re not going to go gentle into that good night.'

He added of the film: 'I think personally it’s a very timely film in terms of its politics, in terms of the soul it deals with. I think it’s as relevant now than ever. The corruption of politics, how we’ve trampled on our souls in this time, very relevant.'

The film is the ninth feature collaboration between De Niro and Scorsese and their first since Casino in 1995.

Tribute: At The Irishman's London premiere, Harvey said of his co-stars: 'I don’t think anybody has slowed down at all, I think things have gotten deeper, richer, more vital'

Though the film's genre and cast has led some to expect a gangster thriller in the mould of GoodFellas or Casino, The Irishman is a more reflective, less flashy rumination on morality, violence and American power.

Through de-aging visual effects, the performances by De Niro, Joe Pesci and Pacino span decades of their characters' lives.

It stars De Niro as Sheeran, a mafia hitman and high-ranking Teamster official.

Shortly before his death, the real Sheeran confessed to killing Jimmy Hoffa (played here by Pacino) — a confession that remains in dispute, with Hoffa's disappearance officially unsolved.

The Irishman hits UK screens on November 8, before being released on Netflix on November 27.
